item.title: Canonicalization
item.description: It’s all canonicalization! God fucking damn-it, every single time there is a problem is always because of an

2 way associativy autmatically gives n-way associativity! Basically on a bin tree, if we can do the transformation:

.

/
B C [ADD SHCEMA OF ] =>

Then we can take any tree, keep the leaves fixed, and mess with the composition, while still mintaing equilvalence

You can reduce this to a canonicalization issue (i.e. from any parenthization, can we get to having it be, say, left associative)

(A((BC)D))

2 opposing tendencies wrt raw materials:

  • (#1) Harder to mine the more time passes (low hangin rfruites akk rich or easy to mine mines becmoe less plentiful)
  • (#2) The more we mine, the more sphisticated large scale stuff we can build to use those resources effieintly (or pivot to other things).

Analogously:

  • (#1) The more people, teh more quickly we cosmuem resources
  • (#2) the more people, the more smart people can work on making extraction more efficient

Can #2 outrun #1? Sure hope so !!

Mean is a commutative but not associative operator!

m(x,y) = (x + y) / 2

m(m(1,2),3) = m(M(2,1), 3) = m()

m(m(1,2), 3) != m(1, m(2,3))

1. Why do we treat multiplication and addition so differently. Isn;t one just repeating the other?
  2. Why do Sylow groups matter?
  3. So ideals are the ring theory equivalent of normal subgroups: Subgroups <=> SUbring: they have to be closed wrt operator (add and mult, resp). Normal Subgroups <=> Ideals: on top of conditions above, we also need to be closed wrt to conjugacy (resp add, mult) wrt to all the elements outside of the group. Question? Why is the absorption 1condition imposed on mult rather
Expceted orthongonallity of 2 random vectors in R^n.

In RL, having state and action be separate only makes sense if the action has a non-deterministic change on the state (but e.g. in LLMs this is not the case, as outputting a new token updates the state predictably). In which situation does updating the state has an not-fully predictable change in the state of the world??

Mesopotamia 2000BC:

Yearly Yield per Hectar of Land: 1.56 +- 0.28 t/ha [https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/abs/pii/S0305440300905697]

Man Hours to go end-to-end on a hectare of land: …

Wheat Caloric Density: …

Assume that 40% is lost and 10% is planted back

Worker: assume 2500 cal / day, 50hrs per week.

Pessimistic: Optimistic: Geo Mean:

Side Thing
